For this pilot's widow, Sarkozy's Libyan funding case is personal
description: The 1989 bombing of UTA Flight 772, ordered by the Libyan regime of Muammar Gaddafi, robbed Maryvone Raveneau of her husband. As a plaintiff in the trial of Nicolas Sarkozy, who is accused of having struck a deal with Gaddafi, she has been disappointed by the media battle waged by the former French president and his supporters.

100 years of the photobooth: Meet the people keeping them alive
description: Created in New York in 1925, the analog photobooth has come close to extinction over the years. Two passionate restorers, Eddy Bourgeois and Virginie Voisneau, are helping keep the vintage booth alive in France and beyond.

headline: 'I wonder why I take pleasure in this': Young men struggle to break free from rape fantasies in porn
description: Some male pornography users have expressed guilt over the videos that arouse them and are trying to reinvent their sexual imagination.

headline: When Christmas presents are secondhand: 'My sisters looked at me strangely'
description: Far from consumerist extravaganzas like 'Black Friday' or 'Cyber Monday,' some people in France prefer to turn to secondhand and recycled goods for their holiday shopping. Juggling the risks of technical failure and the fear of being seen as 'cheapskates,' they share their experiences.

headline: 'The Voice of Hind Rajab' is more than a film about a child killed in Gaza
description: Kaouther Ben Hania's unprecedented work is less a film about Gaza and Hind Rajab, who was killed by Israeli tanks, than it is about our individual and collective powerlessness to stop the horror of mass killings, writes columnist Jean-Pierre Filiu.

description: The document released by the White House on Friday, in which Washington's traditional alliances no longer entail any real commitment, marks a historic break from the post-1945 era.

headline: Katherine Fleming and Los Angeles's Getty Center: A fortress of culture amid political turmoil
description: The president of the renowned arts institution on the West Coast, which withstood the wildfires earlier this year, seeks to further open the museum to the public.

headline: 'Notre-Dame de Paris's triumph highlights the Church's uncharitable position in refusing to charge tourists'
description: Not charging the millions of visitors who flock to the Paris cathedral each year is incomprehensible when considering the dire state of public finances devoted to the conservation of France's religious heritage, writes Le Monde's Michel Guerrin in his column.
